**Pass**—wild geese do not form a line.

**Literary Prosperity**—draws near to the noble and fosters kinship.

**Fortune**—becomes wealthy, possesses loyalty and deference.

**Emolument**—fame and emolument.

**Staff**—true division.

**Anomaly**—contracts differ.

**Mao**—without it, strife and quarrels arise.

**Punishment**—disharmony, strife, and punishment.

**Yao Blade**—weeping and wailing, harm prevails; if the division is great, rely on one’s children.

The song says:
Within the **Brothers Palace**, noble and base divide,
**Void, Anomaly, Punishment, Yao**—none are gladly seen.
If **Heavenly Nobility** and **Red Bird** appear,
Wild geese form a line—how enviable the scene!

If **Heavenly Anomaly** resides in the **Brothers** position,
Brothers must live apart.
Though they share an ancestral home,
In the end, they part ways.

**Heavenly Anomaly** in the **Brothers** place
Demands they be born of different mothers.
Even if they dwell under one roof,
Strife and quarrels will persist.

**Void, Weeping, Yao, Punishment**—none heed reason,
Strange omens arise from the stars.
If **Red Bird** and **Heavenly Nobility** appear,
A line forms, like crows alighting, in kinship they gather.

Brothers should meet **Seal** and **Longevity**’s prosperity,
If they encounter **Yao** or **Anomaly**, daughters will be many.
**Red Bird, Literary Prosperity, Anomaly, Staff**—all take precedence,
But what of **Weeping, Blade, Mao, Punishment**? Alas, what can be done?

**Fourth: The Palace of Fields and Dwellings**
Favor **Pass** and **Treasury** when stars are in exaltation or vigor;
**Heavenly Anomaly** is inauspicious—parents die young.
If **Treasury** and **Heavenly Intent** shine together,
First ruin, then success—this is a fate of self-reliance.

**Purple, Nobility, Seal, Ancestral Fruit**—abundant.
**Fortune, Treasury, Talent**—if above flourish, much evil harms the father.

**Pass** with **Talent**—avoid clashes and ruptures.

**Longevity**—level.

**Red**—fields and dwellings flourish; **Literary Prosperity, Emolument**—abundant grain.

**Void, Staff, Blade**—first enjoy blessings.

**Anomaly**—breaks ancestral ties.

**Mao**—often breaks, often succeeds.

**Yao**—breaks ancestral ties.

**Punishment**—self-destruction, self-achievement.

**Weeping** combined with **Treasury** or **Pass**—first ruin, then success; if in exaltation or vigor, property surpasses ancestral fields.

**Void**—self-achievement, self-reliance.

Fields and dwellings meeting **Mao, Void, Anomaly**—
Ancestral property and talent vanish like dust.
If **Treasury** or **Pass** shine upon the self,
First ruin, then success—one establishes anew.

**Fortune, Emolument, Seal, Longevity**—many fields and dwellings.
**Yao, Mao, Punishment, Anomaly**—parents’ burdens weigh heavy.
First ruin, then success—**Seal** breaking is auspicious.
**Heavenly Void**—fields and dwellings come to naught.

**Fifth: The Palace of Sons and Daughters**
The poem says: In the five positions, life abounds,
Children and grandchildren fill the eye.
Yet male and female stars should not shine here,
For they bring misfortune—**Weeping, Void** too cause early death, many do not survive.

**Three Days’ Office**—in high and strong positions, good for generating **Fortune** and **Emolument**.

The body traverses degrees—twins;
The moon in inauspicious traversal—two share the breast.

**Purple**—one or two children, first daughter, then son;
In exaltation or vigor, children and grandchildren are noble and flourishing;
In prosperous places, four or five children form a line.

**Nobility**—two or three children, glory for posterity.

**Void**—in old age, no children, or none survive;
Otherwise, drifting in foreign lands.
Only adopted children bring joy.
If not, children suffer illness.

**Treasury, Longevity, Seal, Pass**—children bring honor to the family.

**Red**—many daughters, few sons survive.

**Fortune, Literary Prosperity**—three to five children, wealth and nobility;
Avoid clashes and ruptures.

**Emolument**—brings glory, children who change the family’s reputation.

**Staff**—children do not survive, or barely do.

**Weeping**—harm and loss; one or two may see one through to the end.

**Anomaly**—estranged nurturing; children are hard to come by;
One may be raised by a relative, or else an adopted child.

**Mao**—male and female children cause ancestral violence and violent death;
If favorably placed, children bring blessings.

**Blade**—children suffer illness, break the family estate;
Avoid harm and loss—adopted children are the exception.

**Yao**—male and female children are of little help, drifting;
Sons are unruly, daughters impure.

**Punishment**—children are as if absent, unfilial.
If auspicious stars share the palace,
One in three children may see one through to the end.
If the three harmonies meet with evil stars, none are born;
Male and female children are adopted.
Women suffer birth calamities.

**Pass**—two or three children survive.

The poem says:

**Mao**—must not reside over sons and daughters;
Children and daughters-in-law are born like raging tigers.
If encountering Celestial Nobility or Red Phoenix,
Descendants will naturally rise in glory.

**Mao** with Punishment and Blade is fiercely violent;
If Void and Weeping converge, it bodes ill fate.
Should both palaces be graced by auspicious stars,
Servants and descendants will know joy and ease.

**Four Malefics** with Punishment and Flesh—within the womb, deformity is certain.
**Anomaly**—anomalous star governs anomalous births;
If it falls upon progeny, discord follows.
Miscarriages and stepchildren are but trifling matters—
Even a wife’s elder brother may bring them forth.

**Three Punishments** clash with life—before birth, the mother’s body is surely harmed.
**Literary Brilliance** yields many children, though Purple and Red are sparse;
The eldest son is hard to come by, and the staff is but an empty token.
**Seal** and **Longevity** stars beget two sons;
**Fortune** star’s sons and daughters are also worthy of esteem.

**Sixth Palace of Servants**
Must not see **Literary Brilliance**—such a one is less wise than their servants.
**Celestial Blade** and **Celestial Staff** govern strong servants.
If **Weeping** and **Void** appear, banditry is no concern.
**Purple** is difficult to manage.
**Staff**, **Blade**, **Longevity**, **Fortune**, **Weeping**, **Pass**, **Red**, and **Emolument**—servants stand in awe.
**Literary** and **Void**—intelligence cannot distinguish servants.
**Nobility** and **Seal** must not secretly advance or flee.
**Mao** and **Punishment**—servants are fierce and malicious by nature.
**Yao** and **Anomaly**—maidservants prove capable.
If the **Servant Palace** is weak, they follow their mother upon marriage;
At the time of betrothal, they must be exchanged or held by the father.
**Purple** and **Literary** are ill-suited for servants;
**Void** star’s wisdom is inferior to that of servants.
If encountering **Staff** and **Blade**, they prove capable;
**Celestial Punishment** and **Mao**—servants are absent.
**Yao** and **Anomaly**—maidservants are dependable;
**Storehouse** and **Emolument** attract many able servants.

**Seventh Palace of Wives and Concubines**
Should **Red Phoenix** and **Celestial Nobility** shine upon it,
One gains a beautiful and noble wife, along with servants and maids.
Must not see **Celestial Anomaly**—it foretells separation,
Or caution against loss, leading to remarriage.
**Purple** in the court brings a wife of noble appearance.
If debilitated, she is wanton and dissolute.
A woman who marries peacefully is often one who cultivates the Dao,
Practices virtue, and reaps good karma.
Both men and women possess decisiveness.
**Void** governs loss and harm—delay marriage to avoid misfortune.
It may also mean no wife, or many encounters with monks and Daoists.
**Nobility** brings a wife of beauty and purity.
**Seal** gains wealth through his wife; with **Staff**, they do not age together.
**Longevity** suits elderly couples.
**Void** and **Wood** are auspicious.
**Red** brings a wife of lovely countenance.
**Storehouse** gains wives and concubines, though not in old age.
**Emolument** brings a noble wife, but shuns inauspicious stars in opposition.
**Literary** brings a wife of wit and cleverness;
If **Hanging** and the three directions are afflicted by malefics, caution is needed.
**Pass** governs a wife of improper conduct for men,
And a husband of poor character for women.
In the positions of **Si**, **Wu**, **Jia**, and **Hai**, there is no sorrow—
It also signifies a wife of talent.
**Fortune** brings a virtuous and kind wife,
But if afflicted by **Anomaly** or **Punishment**, it is inauspicious.
**Staff** brings solitary or sickly spouses.
**Mao** harms and clashes with a strong-willed wife.
**Anomaly** harms two or three, and discord prevails—
Otherwise, it portends separation.
It may also indicate remarriage, which is ill for both men and women.
**Blade**—men are harmed by wine and lust, women face peril in childbirth.
It also brings hardship, neglect, and frequent harm.
**Punishment** brings harm and loss—delaying may avert it.
**Celestial Staff**—couples suffer many illnesses and worries, and must guard against favored concubines.
**Yao** with remarriage also brings harmony.
But if **Staff**, **Anomaly**, and malefics converge, it foretells separation in life or death.
If in an exalted position or encountered in favorable years, it adds longevity,
And harmonious affairs bring contentment.
**Weeping** often brings punishment and calamity.

The poem says:
In the seventh palace, free of malefics,
Lute and zither harmonize in song.
If husband and wife part ways, their paths diverge—
Yet if Red Phoenix and Nobility favor them,
A virtuous wife and noble sons bring stability;
Weeping stars here bring only sorrow.
Nobility, Seal, and Longevity make for good spouses;
Void, Blade, Mao, and Punishment bring harm.
If the three directions meet with malefics,
Remarriage two or three times is likely.
Punishment, Void, Mao, and Blade bring multiple wives—
Only Red Phoenix grants a wife of rare beauty.
Nobility, Yao, Storehouse, and Emolument bring wives of talent;
Celestial Anomaly foretells separation or estrangement.

**Eighth Palace of Illness and Calamity**
Must not see **Yao** or **Anomaly** stars—
They bring hunchbacks, stooped backs, and severe foot ailments.
○ **Purple**, **Void**, **Nobility**, **Longevity**, **Yao**, **Mao**, **Void**
**Anomaly**—chronic illness, afflictions of the eyes, hands, and feet,
Lung congestion, wheezing, and constant coughing.
○ **Seal**, **Red**, **Storehouse**, **Pass**, **Literary**, **Blade**—**Fortune** and **Emolument**
○ **Yao** and **Weeping**—internal organs are unsettled,
Bringing hunchbacks and lame feet.
If the **Palace of Illness and Calamity** at birth aligns with **Human** and **Horse**,
Or shares the same region as the **Ghost Gate**,
And is debilitated or afflicted by **Blade**, **Anomaly**, or **Punishment**,
The harm extends to the **Wings**, leading to muteness.
**Blade** and **Punishment** in the **Palace of Illness and Calamity** are feared—
The five organs rebel, and treatment is ineffective.
Lame feet, hunchbacks, and stooped backs,
Year after year, weeping and illness are inevitable.
Where does the **Body Star** fall into debility?
If it meets malefics, it is most inauspicious.
If the **Eight Malefics** converge and shine upon it,
One knows the essence and vitality will surely be harmed.
The **Palace of Illness and Calamity** must not see **Celestial Yao**—
**Anomaly** star brings strange and perplexing troubles.
**Punishment** and **Blade** bring frequent illness;
**Celestial Nobility** and **Literary Brilliance** may mitigate them.
**Yao**, **Anomaly**, **Mao**, and **Punishment** bring chronic ailments;
Relying on minor **Fortune** and **Longevity** averts disaster.
Auspicious and inauspicious stars intermingle—examine closely;
If malefics approach, misfortune follows.

**Ninth Palace of Migration**
Must not see **Mao**, **Punishment**, or **Blade** shining upon it—
Traveling abroad brings risks of bandits and violent perils,
In severe cases, even death; observe whether benevolent stars offer salvation.
**Purple**—traveling and residing abroad brings proximity to nobility.
**Void**—leaving one’s homeland enhances talent.
**Seal**—abroad, one gains talent and emolument.
**Nobility**—traveling and residing abroad brings the aid of noble persons.
**Longevity**—traveling abroad is auspicious.
**Storehouse** and **Pass**—abroad, one gains talent and good fortune.
**Red**—abroad, one enjoys talent and joyous occasions;
Meeting the **Three Harmonies** brings auspicious talent—
This pertains to the nine schools of Confucianism and the various arts.
**Literary**—traveling and residing abroad brings proximity to nobility and good fortune.
**Fortune**—migration brings success;
Meeting the **Three Harmonies** with auspicious stars, one travels as they please.
**Emolument**—often encounters high nobility.
**Staff**—traveling and residing abroad are inauspicious.
**Mao**—on the road, one encounters bandits, harm, and violent misfortune,
And may also face water-related calamities.
**Anomaly**—one finds no peace or tranquility.
**Yao**—traveling and residing abroad bring harmony with others.
**Blade**—distant journeys attract bandits.
**Punishment**—distant journeys are inauspicious;
If **Celestial Weeping** is encountered, bandits and violent misfortunes follow.

Weeping—distant journeys and travel bring much quarreling, slander, and strife.
Void—all affairs come to naught.

**Song:**
When moving or traveling, if Punishment and Blade meet Mao,
One must encounter thieves and robbers on the road.
If no auspicious stars come to the rescue of an unnatural death,
Only without malevolent stars need one have no worry.

When Celestial Nobility wanders and travels, one frequently meets the noble;
Seal, Vegetation, Fortune, and Emolument may draw near.
Though Mao, Punishment, and Blade guard in vain against thieves,
One may yet become a wandering ghost in a foreign land.

**Palace of the Ten Officials and Emolument**
It is auspicious to see Seal, Ribbon, and Literary Brilliance—
One attains scholarly rank at the imperial examination.
If in a temple or at its peak, one holds high office and is promoted.
If Void Star appears, one’s life lacks emolument.

When Purple Name returns to the Golden Bowl and enters the temple,
One’s fame reaches the imperial ear, and life flows without cease,
Unentangled in strife.
If meeting Phoenix in youth, one passes the examination;
If broken by opposition, one does not attain nobility.

Void brings an empty reputation—
A strange person whose power is naturally indecisive.
Nobility—when meeting affairs, one fears nothing;
Without malevolence, one’s life is peaceful and secure.

Seal—one can govern the household,
Further gains land, and with mutual resonance of Celestial Nobility,
One is destined to be a general, enfeoffed as a marquis—
A life of great nobility.
If in youth one passes the examination, one early wields banners;
If a commoner does not gain land, one still lives in tranquility.

Longevity entering the temple—
In youth, one passes the imperial examination,
Compassionate toward the multitude, seeing affairs from afar.
Emolument is as above.

Red possesses benevolence and righteousness—
One gains felicity, delights in propriety, and avoids recklessness.
Treasury—good at planning, talent, and calculation;
Entering the temple, one’s name spreads among Chinese and barbarians.

Linked—throughout life, one is kind and decisive;
If broken, it is inauspicious.
Mao—undaunted by affairs, one is not afraid of being slighted.

Weeping removes literary grace.
Literary entering the temple—
In youth, one attains scholarly rank, holds a banner and staff,
A gentleman of pure office, or a monk or Daoist of purity;
A commoner draws near to the noble.

Yao—easily provoked to evil, one must guard one’s words;
Many affairs, many words.

**Poem:**
When in the Palace of Celestial Emolument, Punishment and Staff shine,
Exile and penal servitude are not worth mentioning.
If Celestial Weeping further strikes in opposition,
One dies in penal servitude, wounded or perished—misfortune visits itself.

Of official emolument, Punishment and Blade cannot be spoken;
Imprisonment and litigation entangle, calamities connect.
If Celestial Seal and Literary Brilliance reside in this place,
In youth, one gains high promotion in an unexpected land.

Official emolument must meet Seal and Noble Star;
Staff, Micro, Red, and Longevity are all mediocre.
Celestial Void, Punishment, and Blade bring no substantial achievement;
Only if meeting Literary Brilliance does one’s great name spread.

**Palace of the Eleven Fortunes and Virtues**
It is auspicious to see Fortune, Longevity, and Seal—auspicious stars;
Further auspicious if in a temple or at its peak.
If common Void Star shines and breaks it, one’s life lacks fortune,
Or falls into ruin.

If Punishment and Blade approach,
One must suffer deafness, blindness, goiter, or tumors.
Purple, Longevity, and Red—throughout life, clothing and food are secure and peaceful.
Nobility and Literary—clothing and emolument are pure and abundant.

Seal spreads one’s name.
Treasury—wealth and emolument.
Linked—unconventional talent.
Fortune—firm and steadfast.
Emolument—official emolument.

Staff and Anomaly—laborious, toiling, advancing and retreating.
Mao, Yao, Blade, and Weeping—one’s fortune is meager and inauspicious.
Void—throughout life, one lacks wealth,
One’s person is in a ruined place;
If further met by Punishment and Blade,
One must suffer illnesses of the ears, eyes, mouth, nose, arms, or feet.

Punishment—labor of the heart, resentment, calamity, and penal servitude.
If Void and Weeping further strike, one is wounded or perishes;
If meeting auspicious stars, half is saved.
Yao—one’s body is disordered, one’s heart is busy.

**Song:**

Fortune and virtue unseen—where Heaven’s Void prevails,
The blessed alone remain untouched by bale.
If Punishment and Anomaly cast their baleful light,
Even without illness, one lives in dread and plight.

When the Body Palace stands pure and auspicious, fret not over fate;
Fortune and virtue, steadfast and lofty, transcend all debate.
The Palace of Fortune and Virtue must host propitious stars,
For youth to enjoy ease and honor, free from scars.

Should malevolent luminaries meet the Seal without grace,
Early loss befalls wife, servants, and brothers in their place.

Twelfth: The Palace of Appearance
Fitting to encounter Void and Weeping—through life, few woes.
Ill-suited for Body and Destiny—if Mao and Heavenly Weeping align,
Disfigurement follows; meeting Nobility brings great fortune benign.
Purple—lone qi.
Nobility—crimson, literary, fair of face.
Seal—authority and might.
Longevity—ancient visage.
Treasury—talent revealed.
Linked—sudden rise.
Void—illness and calamity shun its clash.
Fortune and emolument in exalted palaces—from nothing, glory and wealth amass.

Staff—later affliction and distress.
Yao—fair and refined.
Mao—ugly visage.
Weeping—appearance marred by illness.
Anomaly, Blade, Punishment—disfigurement, affliction, and distress.

**Song:**
The Palace of Appearance must not meet Weeping’s sorrow,
Lest wounds mar the face, a limp shoulder follow.
If this palace encounters such baleful rays,
Illness and misfortune surely blight one’s days.

**Song:**
The Palace of Appearance must not meet Anomaly’s star,
Nor Punishment and Blade draw near from afar.
If Body and Destiny these luminaries behold,
Hidden illness and strange calamities unfold.

**Song:**
The Palace of Appearance with Literary Brilliance is not ideal,
But Fortune and Longevity bestow long years, serene and real.
If inauspicious stars assail, ancestral ties may break,
Red Phoenix and Heavenly Weeping—examine for truth’s sake.

In the Zi, Shen, Si, and You palaces, Purple Qi stands high and strong,
For priests and shamans, a share in lofty destinies belong.
○ Star name: Purple Tenuity, dwelling in Zi’s domain.
For men—halls of learning, academies; for women—embroidery and silk’s artful gain.
Without Mao’s touch, men don crowns and reap emolument’s store;
Without Blade’s reach, women grace noble chambers evermore.
If in Si’s palace, or You and Hai’s course it flows,
Fortune and emolument overflow, and fame bestows.

The Purple Qi’s star, when lone, makes monks, nuns, or wanderers of the way,
Or those who follow after, in its solitary sway.

**Song:**
This star in decline—through life, a scholar old,
Yet if in Zi’s palace Purple Tenuity takes hold,
Wealth, nobility, and renown spread far and wide,
Punishment and Anomaly absent—harmony abides.

**Song:**
Purple Qi returns to its proper sphere,
Master of letters, peerless and clear.
In Hai, You, Zi, and Si’s embrace,
Riches, longevity, talent, and virtue grace.
Clad in purple, girded with gold—none compare,
What fear of rank unadorned or honor rare?

**Song:**
Purple Qi meets Purple Qi—celestial splendor bright,
Auspicious stars conjoin to double its light.
Lone Constellation and Heavenly Opposition idle in their station,
Destined for Daoist or Buddhist vocation.
Body and Destiny meet it—longevity assured,
Purple Qi in glory—bliss is secured.
Nobility and prominence in the imperial court reside,
With Heavenly Blade as aide, a minister’s rank applied.

**Song:**
Purple Qi—artists of leisure, refined,
With Ghost and Net—skill is defined.
Versed in civil and martial arts, strategy profound,
Empty realms bring glory, all things renewed and sound.

Purple Tenuity delights in its central throne,
Wealth and treasure overflow, fortune’s bounty sown.
In the Palace of Children and Destiny, official rank,
Meeting it—elegance and success in all things rank.

Heavenly Void—ice’s essence, Yin’s form in Wu’s noon.
○ Star name: Heavenly Void, meeting Body and Destiny’s boon.
In Yin, Shen, Si, and Hai’s four palaces, wealth is thin,
Yet in Xu, Chou, and Wu—glory and riches begin.
If fallen in officialdom, ruin leaves no trace,
Better to gather idle winds, beneath plum blossoms’ grace,
In paper curtains, alone to sleep in tranquil space.

**Song:**
Heavenly Remainder in Chou and Wu—true wealth and might,
Si, Hai, Yin, Shen—much is empty, slight.
If Mao’s head joins in its gaze,
Fields and gardens vanish in ruin’s haze.

**Song:**
Heavenly Void in Chou and Wu’s position thrives,
In its temple’s glory, no harm survives.
False words and deceitful hearts—heed them not,
For schemes may prosper, riches begot.

**Song:**
Peach and plum in spring’s silent bloom,
Who shares the willow’s verdant plume?
Heavenly Void melts in celestial flame,
Striking wealth and rank—half a life in shame.
If good stars intercede to save,
Half fortune lingers, half misfortune’s wave.

**Song:**
Advance—a mate of equal grace,
Retreat—worldly ties still trace.
Heavenly Void in temple, Body and Destiny’s guest,
Yin and Yang in harmony—bliss is blessed.
Though malevolent stars may join the throng,
Even in success, dust clings to the brow’s song.

Heavenly Nobility—Earth’s essence, Yin’s form in Yin and Chen’s morn.
○ Star of Destiny: Heavenly Nobility, fame and renown are born.
In Yin and Chen’s two palaces, in its rightful place,
Wealth abounds, glory and riches grace,
Servants attend, few calamities arise,
All schemes prosper, a thousandfold life’s prize.

**Song:**
Heavenly Nobility in Yin and Chen shines bright,
Mao’s head conjoined—no splendor in its light.
Staff’s star added—poverty and lowly state,
Like Xuanzhou’s flowering quince—fate’s cruel bait.

**Song:**
Heavenly Nobility—star of temple’s might,
In Shen, Zi, Chen, and Hai’s domains, it takes its flight.
Youth brings elegance, fame’s sweet sound,
Golden lists proclaim, fortune’s blessings abound.

**Song:**
Heavenly Nobility—from emolument and virtue’s claim,
If in Body and Destiny, a palace’s frame,
With Literary and Seal stars nearby to gleam,
It guides one to office, purple robes to seam.

Nobility’s star in temple, in Body and Destiny’s keep,
In its season, fortune and emolument run deep.
Wealth like towering peaks, boundless and grand,
Official rank among the Three Dukes to command.

Heavenly Seal—Yang’s form, Earth’s essence in Zi, Mao, Chen, and Hai’s tide.
○ Star of Destiny: Heavenly Seal, upon Body and Destiny bestride.
For women—keen of heart; for men—renown’s pride.
If malevolent stars stay far, early authority is tied.
Should Anomaly draw near, untimely death or illness’s fear,
A life with little fortune, half in woe’s frontier.
If Heavenly Staff appears, borrowed power in official spheres,
Concubines may bear sons, but the wife remains barren for years.

**Song:**
Heavenly Seal—originally a star benign,
Mao’s head alone makes it malign.
Delighting in Zi and Mao’s two palaces’ sway,
Wielding military power, a general’s array.

**Song:**
Heavenly Seal—originally a star benign,
In Zi, Mao, Chen, and Si—glory’s design.
High office, weighty authority—all admire,
Resounding fame shakes the imperial spire.

**Song:**
Heavenly Seal upon the body—power’s might,
Threefold support strengthens its light.
Nobility and prominence in the imperial court reside,
With Heavenly Blade as aide, a minister’s rank applied.

If neither Void Weeping nor Mao’s Anomaly draws near,
Wealth and nobility unite, a century to revere.
When Seal Star enters its temple, most wondrous indeed,
Misfortune dissolves, and fortune follows with speed.
Crucial is the meeting of auspicious stars in one’s fate,
Youth ascends the celestial ladder, swift and great.

**Heavenly Longevity**
Symbol: Yang, Earth, in Hai, You, and Xu
Longevity Star stands alone—sons ensure no solitude.
Official misfortune never arises in life’s span,
Calamities vanish, leaving none to withstand.
If not ensnared in ruin’s snare,
Fortune abounds, and wealth beyond compare.
Should no malevolent stars dwell in its native palace,
Lifespan rivals Peng Zu’s, boundless and flawless.

**Song:**
In Si, Hai, and Wu palaces, Heavenly Treasury’s store,
Jade and gold accumulate, beyond all count or lore.
Should Mao’s Weeping draw too near, base illness may arise,
Yet youth recalls events of centuries with clear, unclouded eyes.

**Song:**
Heavenly Treasury graces the Lion’s palace bright,
Or in Si and Hai—its glory shines with equal light.
If the three directions bear no baleful stars in sight,
Jade and gold amass, a wealthy lord’s delight.

**Song:**
Treasury Star in temple named Heaven’s Aid,
Wisdom and cunning craft each plan it laid.
Gold and silver need not toil to secure,
Fame or fortune—either path is sure.

**Literary Brilliance**
Symbol: Yang, Wood, in Yin, Wu, and Xu
○ Star named Literary Prosperity, upon fate and body cast,
Men’s words like scattered pearls, women’s embroidery unsurpassed.
Though youth may shun the scholar’s path, renown still finds its way,
Official rank and salary through literary prowess sway.
In Yin, Wu, and Xu palaces, most wondrous its display,
Literary Star and noble hosts fill heaven’s vault each day,
Youth excels in imperial exams, crowns the host of peers.
Yet Heavenly Staff’s approach brings poverty and years,
A century’s name in vain, a hollow, fleeting sphere.

**Song:**
Literary Brilliance in Xu, with Yin and Wu aligned,
There, glory dons gold and purple, noble and refined.
From the imperial academy, fame resounds afar,
With writings peerless, a scholar’s name shines like a star.

**Song:**
Literary Brilliance in temple, flourishing and bright,
Assuredly brings wisdom and world-renowned light.
Even in decline, high favor may yet be found,
In public and private spheres, a name of renown abounds.

**Song:**
When Literary Brilliance and auspicious stars unite,
One scales the loftiest ranks, surpassing all in sight.
Red Phoenix’s talent—exquisite, rare,
Beauty and fortune harmonize beyond compare.
If Fortune and Virtue upon fate and body rest,
Surely both blessings follow, doubly blessed.

**Song:**
Red Phoenix in temple graces fate and form,
A visage fair as Guanyin, serene and warm.
In temperament and nature, gentle, mild, and kind,
Surpassing all, the crowd’s esteem they bind.

**Coiled Rope**
Symbol: Yin, Earth, in Mao, Si, Wu, Wei, and Hai
○ Star named Coiled Rope, upon fate and body cast,
Life marked by frequent rises, frequent falls—half joy, half woe at last.
With Mao’s Head drawing near, like Yanzi’s early end,
Yet Staff Star’s light may lengthen life, to Peng Zu’s years extend.
In Si and Hai palaces, its temple’s power grows,
Late years bring wealth and salary, prosperity bestows.

**Song:**
Coiled Star in Si and Hai stands strong and high,
Household thrives, fields and estates multiply.
Heavenly Staff’s near light brings sons in store,
Yet Mao’s Weeping leaves but one to deplore.

**Song:**
Coiled Rope’s star, by name Profound Mystery,
In Wei, Shen, Si, and Hai, its threads entwine.
Gold and jade fill halls, piled high as earth,
Wealth and salary overflow, ten thousand fields of worth.

**Song:**
Coiled Rope’s star, by name Profound Subtlety,
In fate, its presence marks a root most free.
If Heaven’s Anomaly and Mao’s Head keep their distance,
Peace and advantage reign, life’s course resilient.

**Heavenly Treasury**
Symbol: Yang, Earth, in Mao, Si, Hai, and Wu
○ Star named Heavenly Treasury—wealth and nobility attend,
Women amass fields and estates, men rise to ranks ascend.
In Si, Hai, and Wu, fortunes multiply,
Facing peril unshaken, danger defied.
This star’s native bears three sons, one remains,
As Blade and Executioner their paths constrain.

**Song:**
Heavenly Longevity graces life with lengthened span,
Hai and You palaces its finest plan.
If Blade or Weeping should their light impart,
Future holds a marquis’s rank, a kingly heart.

**Song:**
Heavenly Longevity, a star of fortune’s sign,
Delights in You and Hai, where life extends its line.
Should auspicious stars their radiance bestow,
Lifespan strengthens, fortune and salary grow.

**Song:**
Heavenly Longevity, born as Old Man’s star,
In fate and body dwelling, noble beyond par.
Revered for virtue and fortune, all gaze with awe,
In fame and salary, wealth and honor draw.

**Song:**
Auspicious Longevity holds fortune’s sway,
In temple’s glory, blessings naturally stay.
Abroad, a general; at court, a minister’s role,
All proclaim the worthy, a sage of olden scroll.

**Red Phoenix**
Symbol: Yin, Metal, in Chen, Chou, and Yin
Star named Red Phoenix—tall of stature, form,
Men wed early, women face no harm.
In Chen and Chou, wisdom, wealth, and grace,
Without baleful stars to mar the way,
A radiant life spans eighty years’ embrace.
Red Phoenix’s auspicious light brings beauty’s face.

**Song:**
Red Phoenix’s joy—what bliss it brings,
Yet Mao’s Head’s baleful star must not take wings.
Should Executioner or Blade their light combine,
Like frost-struck lotus, half the pond’s design.

**Song:**
Red Phoenix’s star has ever been benign,
In Si, Hai, Yin, and Chou, its path divine.
Half a lifetime’s fortune, contentment’s reign,
Nobility and imperial favor, lordly domain.

**Song:**
When fortune’s limit aligns with power’s display,
Gold at the waist, purple robes sway,
Assisting the enlightened sovereign’s way.

**Heavenly Fortune**
Symbol: Yang, Earth, in Shen and Mao
○ Fortune Star’s approach—this fate is most refined,
Women fair of face, dignified in mien,
Men wed early, sons arrive in time.
Without malevolent stars to cloud the scene,
Wealth and treasures multiply, serene.
In Shen and Mao, its power grows,
Free from calamity, free from woes,
Parents and siblings whole, complete,
Husband and wife to a century’s beat.

**Song:**
Heavenly Fortune in Shen and Mao, a scholar’s grace,
Gold at the waist, fine writings trace.
Should Weeping or Void their light impart,
Poverty or early death—both wound the heart.

**Song:**
Heavenly Fortune graces body and fate,
A magnanimous spirit, resolute and great.
With Salary Star’s threefold light aligned,
Destined for glory, wealth, and rank refined.

**Song:**
Heavenly Fortune’s star enters its temple bright,
Best upon body and fate to shed its light.
Fortune and salary flourish, noble sons arise,
Three directions unbroken, salary multiplies.

**Heavenly Salary**
Symbol: Yang, Wood, in Si and Shen
○ Salary Star’s approach—malevolent stars kept at bay,
Wisdom and intelligence mark the way,
All endeavors prosper, each wish fulfilled.
In Si and Shen, fate and body stand fulfilled.
Auspicious stars bring three sons, two remain,
As Mao’s Head lingers, its light sustains.

Should they not share the same path,
Merits and deeds shall flourish, fields be acquired.

**Song:**
When Supreme Ultimate and Heavenly Salary hold their rightful place,
All auspicious stars they meet find their proper station.
If Mao’s Head star does not share the same palace,
Career and renown shall be achieved by one’s own creation.

**Song:**
The Salary Origin star governs scholarly rank,
Adorned in brocade and girded with gold, most noble and grand.
Assisting the sovereign to accomplish great deeds,
One becomes a royal scion, golden branch and jade leaf in the land.

**Song:**
Dwelling in Shen and Si, known as the Three Terraces,
Fortune sweeps away all misfortune, prosperity comes of its own accord.
Wealth and grain accumulate abundantly throughout life,
With literary talent, one shall ascend as the foremost laureate.

**Song:**
Heavenly Salary’s advent brings boundless joy,
Wielding authority, one’s path is widely proclaimed.
With fortune and Wenchang’s grace in full array,
Heroes and valiant men live in ease and acclaim.

**Heavenly Staff**
Symbol: Yang, Wood, in Wei, Hai, Zi, and Shen
Star named Heavenly Staff—concubines bear sons,
Yet men’s marriages yield no heirs, or hardship, poverty, or early death ensue.
When the staff falls in its temple, glory and nobility come without strife.
When it leaps into the palace, purity and kindness bring fortune’s light.

**Song:**

If not clad in fur or bearing horns, one becomes but a servant before donkeys and behind horses.
Yet should the Official Star dwell in Hai or Zi, though rich and noble, one remains solitary in life.

**Song:**
The Heavenly Staff fares best when roaming Hai or Zi,
Or sought in Shen and You as well.
All matters align with heart’s desire, seldom thwarted,
And with added longevity, woes and grief dispel.

**Song:**
In form most comely, in bearing most refined,
In human affairs, none more complete.
When the Heavenly Staff star enters one’s fate,
Auspicious stars lend aid, and benevolent stars align.
Should this luminary appear in the natal chart,
As official or clerk, one moves with ease and grace.

**Song:**
When the staff resides in the lunar position, misfortune reigns—
How then may one ascend the Celestial Gate? Yet if none,
When the Heavenly Staff enters its temple, called the Heavenly Might,
It grasps military power and pacifies the four barbarians.
This is the Authority Star, fierce turned auspicious,
Its heroic renown shining bright without bound.

**Heavenly Anomaly**
Symbol: Yin, Earth, in Chen, Chou, and Wei
Star named Heavenly Anomaly—when the Void Star shares its palace,
Two evils conspire, yet youth does not meet an early end.
Though minor blessings may arise, misfortune prevails,
Parents are afflicted, siblings nonexistent, children few.
Ancestral estates vanish, all destroyed,
A life adrift, wandering east and west.
Yet in Wei, Chou, or Chen’s palace,
Joy abounds when auspicious stars converge, and emoluments multiply.

**Song:**
When life and fate are bound to Anomaly and Void,
Even at lakeside crossings, no sorrow clouds the way.
But if inauspicious stars strike with punitive force,
One drifts like smoke in wind, or embers in the breeze.

**Song:**
The Heavenly Anomaly star bodes ill,
Yet joy comes in Chou, Wei, and Chen’s domain.
In Chen and Si, no harm, but boundless delight,
All undertakings flourish and thrive.

**Song:**
The Leaping of Parting weighs most on the heart,
Heaven’s decree leaves brows knit in vain distress.
A widow with three husbands still finds no content,
A lone man with five wives yet weds not in full.

**Song:**
When the Anomaly star enters its temple, directly in palace,
Wealth and grain accumulate in great abundance.
Within fields and estates, vigor and prosperity reign,
And with life and fate blessed by auspicious stars, all is grand.

**Hairy Head**
Symbol: Yin, Water, in Zi, Mao, Wei, Yin, and Xu
Star named Hairy Head—only joyous when flourishing.
If solitary in course, women harm husbands and children,
While men face repeated marriages, ancestral homes emptied,
Forced to forge their own livelihoods.
Though clothing and food never lack,
Half a lifetime of toil still leads to dissipation and deceit,
For they are not the sort to preserve what’s been built.

**Song:**
In Hairy Head’s domain of Zi, Mao, Yin, and Xu,
Temperaments are serene, dispositions at ease, minds keen.
Men, if not wealthy, must be noble,
Women, if not noble, are sharp of heart.

**Song:**
Hairy Head’s weeping blade cannot be withstood,
Exile and flight mark the path to fame and profit.
Though ancestral estates may be worn away,
What of descendants? Can they endure long?

**Song:**
In Hairy Head’s realm of Zi, Mao, Yin, and Xu,
Fortune and kindness may be slight, yet blessings remain.
When auspicious stars descend to break the lineage’s branch,
One may rise to Heaven’s mandate, guarding the frontier.

**Song:**
Hairy Head, an ill star turned auspicious,
Those afflicted by it face lifelong poverty.
Yet if good stars come to their aid,
Even official troubles may multiply.

**Song:**
When Hairy Head enters its temple, nearing life and fate,
The one it meets should bear the mark of a warrior.
Renown resounds throughout the land,
As they guard the frontier, the four barbarians submit.

**Heavenly Blade**
Symbol: Yin, Metal, in Shen, Si, Wu, Yin, and You
When a single blade pierces the palace, wealth and emolument align,
Yet women harm husbands and children,
While men find no fulfillment in marriage,
Standing alone, though spared from calamity.
Parents and siblings do not remain,
Wives and servants cannot endure long.

**Song:**
When the Heavenly Blade’s blade arrives in layers,
Twofold encounter brings disaster.
With killing stars fourfold, like water and fire,
Youth meeting ill fate turns to ash.

**Song:**
Bloodshed invades fate, wounds and ruin follow,
Punitive blades bring calamity’s embrace.
A six-foot frame may perish to a tiger’s bite,
Or drown in waves, as fate decrees.

**Song:**
When the Blade star and punishment converge, parents suffer,
Men must seek adoption to fare well.
If a woman shares its palace’s light,
Her fate is sealed to wed anew.

**Song:**
Without fortune, the body is maimed, the visage marred,
With salvation, six relations still suffer.
The Heavenly Blade, a star of blood and rebellion, bodes ill,
When its limit arrives, calamity and hardship redouble.
Yet in its temple’s glory, civil and martial nobility may arise,
Beware, though, of underestimating foes, lest all come to naught.

**Song:**
Jade meets the Eight Killings, radiant and bright,
Yet in the Wealth Palace, fortune is incomplete.
If the Punishment Star does not enter its temple,
Snake-belly misfortune strikes that very year.

**Song:**
When the Heavenly Blade dwells in Si, Wu, or Shen,
And meets Yin’s position, glory shines.
Through martial valor, great deeds are achieved,
Fame resounds, authority commands ten thousand troops.

**Song:**
The Heavenly Blade, a baleful star, reaches the White Ram,
Its light illumines the cosmos, fixing the four directions.
Wielding power with masterful hands,
Gaining wealth and prominence, it must be auspicious.

**Heavenly Punishment**
Symbol: Yin, Fire, in Yin, Wu, You, and Xu
When the Punishment Star travels alone, it brings threefold incompletion:
As monk or Daoist, one fails to establish a home,
Yet finds no clarity—solitary, solitary!
If not solitary, then no brothers,
Parents not both whole,
Wives and servants do not endure.
In three palaces, the body is harmed, leading to madness or self-strangulation.

**Song:**

When the Thunderbolt Star strikes one’s fate, how can one not fear?
Meeting Punishment, the body falls—why descend further?
Life is cut short by baleful stars’ approach,
And the man dies beneath the thunder’s wrath.

**Song:**
The Threefold Incompletion Star is Heavenly Punishment,
As monk or Daoist, one is called a solitary soul.
When Blade and Wailing Stars converge above,
Swiftly one becomes a man beset by illness.

**Song:**
The Heavenly Maiden wanders in Xu, Mao, and Chen,
And seeks the Double Fish as well.
Though blessed with fortune, one indulges in wine and desire,
Yet passes through spring and autumn without disaster or calamity.

**Song:**
The Heavenly Maiden is the Xianchi.
Xianchi, a single baleful star, seeks truth alongside,
Meeting water’s allure brings ruin and lewdness.
Bathing in divine favor, one sees only nobility,
Yet the heart teaches the ruin of nations and cities.

**Song:**
The Maiden Star, like the Defeat Star,
Is called the "Sweeping Doom" among mortal stars.
A lifetime of toil and hardship,
Never knowing ease within the home.

**Song:**
When the Heavenly Maiden enters the temple, it brings fortune,
And when fate aligns, prosperity is assured.
Meeting a virtuous wife, blessings and emolument increase,
And like ice growing firm upon the earth, one rises high and strong.

**The Eighteen Stars and Their Affiliations**
Wailing, Blade, Bow, Metal, Fire—these are Punishment,
Purple, Pattern, Staff, Emolument—Wood forms a forest.
Fur, Maiden, Void—Water; Noble, Fortune—Earth,
Seal, Longevity, Treasury, Guanyin—Earth shares their bond.

When any star enters the Body or Fate Palaces,
Examine its Five Phases affiliation,
And discern its timely illumination of the Three Directions and Four Cardinals.
Note which stars reside in harmonious palaces,
And judge their mutual generation, conquest, restraint, and transformation,
To determine fortune, emolument, good, and ill.

**Essential Four-Character Verse Summary from the *Ru Gu Xian Jing***

**Song:**

**The Primordial Unity and the Five Phases**

One qi blends in primordial chaos, the Five Phases yet unseen.
The Three Powers first divide, yin and yang begin their change.

**Shared Birth, Divergent Punishment**
Fortune and misfortune arise, male and female take form.
Shared birth, divergent punishment—all follow this single principle.

**Longevity, Luan, Treasury, Prosperity, and Emolument**
Purple Tenuity, Noble, Seal—Celestial Longevity and Red Luan.
**Purple, Noble, Seal:** Treasury, Linked, Literary Brilliance, and Emolument revolve in harmony.
**Auspicious Luminaries Move Left**
These are called auspicious stars, moving left with the year.
When they illumine Body and Fate Palaces, wealth and nobility are no trifling matter.

**Staff, Divergent, Fur, Blade, Maiden, Wailing—Punishment**
Staff, Divergent, Fur, Blade, Maiden, and Wailing Punishment.
**All Are Called Inauspicious Stars**
These are baleful stars of fate; those who encounter them meet ruin.
Each has its temple and flourishing, cycling without end.

**Purple Tenuity**
Purple Tenuity delights in *shen-zi-si-you-hai*, bringing glory.
Purple resides in *shen-zi*, flourishing in *si-you-hai*.

**Celestial Void**
Celestial Void favors *wu-wu-wei-you-hai*, bringing glory.
*Chen* Palace, *chou-wu*, Jade Hall is most fitting.

**Celestial Noble**
Celestial Noble favors *yin-chen-hai-mao-wei*.
Noble in *yin-chen*, *hai-mao* are suitable abodes.

**Celestial Seal**
Celestial Seal favors *zi-mao-chen*, auspiciously conferring power and nobility.
To which palace is the Seal granted? When Body and Fate encounter it,
In *zi-mao-chen*, one need not seek to become noble.

**Celestial Longevity**
Celestial Longevity delights in *hai-you*, flourishing when entering *yin*.
Celestial Longevity, Old Man Star—examine the Three Directions and Four Cardinals.
In *hai-you-yin* Palaces, opposition and harmony bring smooth fortune.

**Red Luan**
Red Luan favors *chen-chou-yin-mao-hai*.
Red Luan in *chen-chou*, *yin-mao-hai* is excellent.

**Treasury and Linked**
Treasury and Linked favor *mao-si-wu-wei*, Treasury delights in the *hai* position.
The stars of Treasury and Linked—no deviation in their positions is permissible.

**Literary Brilliance**
Literary Brilliance favors *yin-wu-xu*, wondrously granting top imperial examination honors,
And positions as ministers and chancellors.
*Mao-si-wu-wei*, *hai* Earth is also praiseworthy.
**Literary Brilliance**
The constellation of Literary Brilliance—*yin-wu-xu* is most auspicious.

**Celestial Emolument**
Celestial Emolument delights in *yin-mao-si-wu*, *shen* brings ministerial rank.
**Emolument**
Passing imperial examinations, attaining high office—
Emolument in *yin-mao*, *si-wu* brings nobility.

**Celestial Staff**
Celestial Staff favors *zi-shen-hai*, flourishing in frozen harmony and mutual resonance,
Wealth and nobility are beyond doubt.
**Celestial Staff**
Staff in *zi-shen*, *hai-wei* are its temples and flourishing positions.

**These Two Stars**
These two stars favor *zi-mao-wei*, bold and decisive, with abundant wealth.
**Fur Star**
Fur in *zi-mao*, within *wei-yin-xu*.

**Divergent Star**
Divergent Star favors *chou-yin-chen*, *yin-xu* bring great wealth.
Courageous and heroic, swift as lightning.
**Celestial Divergent**
Divergent in *chou-yin*, *chen-wei* brings erudition.

**Celestial Blade**
Celestial Blade favors *shen-si-wu-yin*, Blade in *shen-si*, *wu-yin* finds its footing.

**Celestial Maiden**
Celestial Maiden favors *mao-chen*, entering *xu-hai* Palaces.

Yang men and yin women proceed in sequence; yin men and yang women proceed in reverse.
Start from the palace of one’s birth and life.

**Tai Yi Golden Well: On the Profound Principles of Yin and Yang**
*Beginning of the Second Scroll of the Purple Forbidden Astrology*

A person is endowed with the qi of Heaven and Earth, receiving the essence of yin and yang to give rise to their body and fate. Above, they belong to the Five Stars; below, to the Five Phases. If the timing is correct, their body and fate will be exalted, and their future bright and prosperous. If the timing is incorrect, their fate will be base and their body lowly, sinking into obscurity and drift.

Generally, one’s life must find the stars in their proper positions, with favorable fortune and strength aligning to bring success. Moreover, if one delights in prosperity without affliction, and auspicious stars reside in strong palaces, they are a person of profound fortune. This is predestined, governed by the stars.

In examining fate, first determine the Body Palace, for the body is linked above to the spirit of Tai Yi. If beneficent stars meet with prosperous fortune in their proper positions, forming celestial harmony, this is a life of purity and nobility. Only then should one assess the Fate Palace and the hour, for if these are shallow or unstable, they lack strength. Even with powerful stars, their blessings will be slight. Only when timing is correct and positions proper can one attain glory, virtue, fields and dwellings, official rank, and emolument.

The six palaces’ good and ill determine survival and demise; nobility and baseness fix fortune and misfortune, yielding accurate predictions. Whenever stars reside in palaces of honor or places of joy and prosperity, one must also consider the yin and yang divisions of the palaces. As the classic states: “Yang stars favor goodness; yin stars favor destruction.”

In the two palaces of stars and fate, when the division of hours and quarters yields more yang than yin—such as being born in the first, second, third, or fourth quarter of the hour—one’s fortune will be abundant, life long, parents blessed, siblings harmonious, wife virtuous, and children outstanding. If one’s body and fate further reside in palaces of honor and prosperity, this is a life of the highest rank.

Men born under yang stars are noble births. Those born in the first four quarters will be resolute and blessed. Women born under yin stars are honorable births. Those born from the fifth to the eighth quarter will excel in wifely virtue, enjoy support from maternal kin, harmony with sisters-in-law, a marriage of mutual respect, and children who are both talented and numerous.

One must calculate the hour precisely to gauge fortune and misfortune, determine the harmony of flesh and bone, discern the presence of affliction or conflict, and distinguish between wealth and poverty, wisdom and folly.

Yang stars govern civil matters and thrive in their palaces of honor and prosperity. Occupying the six yang palaces, they produce scholars of refined literary grace. Yin stars govern martial matters and flourish in places of joy and prosperity. Occupying the six yin domains, they produce warriors of courage and resolve.

Whenever stars reside in yang within yang or in yin within yin, each following its kind, this is called “finding its proper position.” The opposite—yin and yang intermingled—is called “not finding its proper position.” The qi one receives may be turbid: within a single day, from *mao* to *shen* (5 a.m. to 5 p.m.) are the six yang hours of daylight; from *you* to *yin* (5 p.m. to 5 a.m.) are the six yin hours of night.

Those born in yin palaces should avoid daytime births; those born in yang palaces should avoid nighttime births. Both positions are unfavorable at the same hour. Further, births occurring at the cusp of day and night, or when the hour straddles upper and lower quarters, require careful assessment of fortune and lifespan. If yin and yang are mixed, the quarters uneven, and the pairing inauspicious, this—beyond mere honor or prosperity—portends a life of meager fortune and short span.

Moreover, one must observe the transiting limits where beneficent or malefic stars enter the moments of body and fate, for this precisely determines fortune and misfortune, all of which will be verified.

**Mid-Chart Noble Destiny:**
When auspicious stars stand high and inauspicious stars lie low, with the life and destiny palaces graced by propitious constellations—**Wenchang** in attendance, auxiliary and seal stars arrayed in the four directions or forming a triple conjunction with fortune-bringing stars, stationed in their proper or exalted palaces—then the auxiliary and seal stars govern eight *ke* of the proper hour, while the nine luminaries occupy positions of strength. If the fortune star resides in its exalted palace, harmoniously aspecting the opposite palace, and the auxiliary star alone stands high over the life and destiny palaces, even a single star in its proper or exalted position shines brightly in a position of strength. Alternatively, if within the three-day palace and the eight *ke*, one occupies the domain of the six yin palaces, with the **Luan** star unaspected by the **Celestial Staff**, the mother enjoys long life, and if further exalted, this denotes a mid-chart noble destiny, a life of wealth and prominence.

**Lower-Chart Noble Destiny:**
When the **Taifu** star alone stands high over the life and destiny palaces, and the three-day palace is fully aspected by three auspicious stars in triple conjunction, this constitutes a lower-chart noble destiny. If the fortune star is exalted and strong while auspicious stars are weak and debilitated, it signifies a lesser noble destiny. Such is the interplay of yin and yang, the harmony of time and moment.

**Common Destiny Outside the Chart:**
When auspicious and inauspicious stars jointly aspect the life palace, and the **Taifu** star is not in its proper position, this denotes the destiny of a wealthy commoner. If the **Taifu** star is weak and debilitated, yet **Hongluan** aspects directly without affliction, and the **Red Luan** forms a harmonious aspect, this signifies a person of immense wealth.

**Destitute and Lowly Destiny:**
When the fortune star is debilitated in **Tianyao**, aspecting both the life and destiny palaces, with the **Xu** star in opposition, this marks the most destitute and lowly destiny—parents lost in early years, siblings few or nonexistent, wives and children harmed. Even if one encounters a favorable period with auspicious stars, wealth does not accumulate, for the root is shallow and weak. Though one may possess literary talent and official emolument, this does not constitute a destiny within the chart.

**Foolish Destiny:**
The **Wenchang** star must not be debilitated, for the six auspicious stars, when in positions of strength, become inauspicious. If they do not reside in their proper palaces, how much more dire the misfortune? Generally, when stars enter the chart, one need not consider official emolument. For scholars, one must examine **Wenchang**; for commoners, one may simply observe **Tianlu** and **Tianzhang** to determine the measure of longevity and prosperity.

**Determining the Aspects of Palace Conjunctions:**
When fortune and longevity jointly aspect **Hongluan**, how can one not be intelligent? When **Xu** and **Yi** together attend **Maotou**, how can one not be dull-witted? If positioned in **Tianyin**, it governs migration and authority; if in **Wenchang**, it lacks the conduct of fortune and emolument. In the **Fields and Estates** palace, granaries overflow with grain; in the **Wealth and Silk** palace, coffers brim with gold and jade. When **Noble Emolument** aspects the **Children** palace, descendants bring glory; when **Storehouse** and **Guan** aspect the **Life and Destiny** palace, one’s future is ever secure, and honor flourishes. If **Yao** and **Yi** entangle the body, longevity is denied; if **Blade** and **Wailing** afflict destiny, **Tianxu** and **Tianren** bring only calamity. **Tianxing** and **Tianzhang**—who could find joy in their presence? When they meet wives and concubines, widowhood is often auspicious; when they enter the **Official Emolument** palace, poverty and illness abound. To encounter these stars in one’s fate is to face imminent peril; to pass beyond their influence is to escape disaster. Thus, destiny knows prosperity and adversity, but not permanence. The successful occupy positions of strength, while the struggling dwell in desolation. Honor, prosperity, and longevity arise from the conjunction of auspicious stars; violence, misfortune, and early death stem from the convergence of inauspicious ones. Without the stars, how could one examine the details? Without fate, how could one know the essentials? With keen focus and deep reflection, one may unlock the mysteries of this text. By discussing the present and exploring the past, one comes to recognize the excellence of this work.

**Life and Death, Poverty and Wealth:**
If not predestined, how could one know? **Nobility and lowliness, prosperity and decay**—these are not matters of chance. The art of divination is both precise and subtle. By studying the classics, one may revisit them thrice and come to understand. To grasp this profound art requires more than a single day. The teachings of the **Four Lords and Three Origins** are as unchanging as true gold; the discourse on the **Five Stars and Six Luminaries** is as invaluable as fine jade. By silently observing the principles of the **Eighteen Stars** and mastering the essentials of the **Twelve Palaces**, one may discern poverty and wealth, nobility and lowliness—none can escape the scrutiny of the fortune stars.

**Man receives the qi of Heaven and Earth, forming the Three Powers.**
Those complete in Heaven, Earth, and Man are called *cheng ren* (perfected persons), and when their fate aligns with prosperity, their wealth endures without limit. Those incomplete in Heaven, Earth, and Man are called *bu cheng ren* (imperfect persons), and when their fate arrives, their wealth collapses without recourse. Generally, those unaspected by **Xu**, **Wailing**, **Punishment**, or **Blade** are complete; those afflicted by them are incomplete. When fate enters a yang palace and encounters a yang star, or enters a yin palace and encounters a yin star, each receives the harmony of Heaven’s timing. To meet the **Wailing** star in a year of avoidance is to see immediate consequences.

**At birth, if the Zi and Hong noble stars reside in the life and destiny palaces,**
the early years bring honor and nobility, with emolument flourishing and expanding. If **Wenchang** and other stars aspect directly or reside in their proper or exalted palaces, auspicious events and joy follow. When **Tianxu** enters one’s fate, wealth and silk dissipate; wherever it aspects, misfortune and strangeness arise. When **Tianyin** enters one’s fate and occupies a position of strength in its proper palace, it brings the joy of wealth and authority. Even if not within the chart, it heralds auspicious events. To encounter **Hongluan** in one’s fate is to wed a woman of beauty or for a woman to marry a man of talent. When the **Xu** star aspects one’s fate, it brings false alarms. **Yao** and **Blade** govern water disasters; **Mao** and **Yi** govern fire calamities, exile, or forced name changes. If one’s fate encounters **Storehouse** and **Guan**, it brings sudden wealth, lifting the poor to riches. For the rest, inauspicious stars follow the guidance of the **Wenchang** star—examining the stars’ positions in their palaces provides the standard, without the slightest error.

Should there be those who die at the very onset of a fate-period, or perish as it draws near, one must rely on the stars of life and death for precise judgment. If the **Tianku** star shines directly upon one’s fate and destiny, it is called the **Yellow Springs star**. If it shines directly upon the fate-period while also opposing it, this is termed the **Raging Waves fate-period**, presaging death and layer upon layer of mourning. In yang palaces, it brings much sorrow; in yin palaces, it may bring some joy. Even if it resides in its proper temple as a fortune star, one cannot escape external bereavement or the wearing of mourning for kin.

*The **Tianku** star is most inauspicious;*
