It also portends violent disaster and death. When in **Zi (Rat)** or **Mao (Rabbit)**, it is at its peak; when in **Wei (Goat)** or **Xu (Dog)**, it delights in **Yin (Tiger)** or the **Life Palace**, making one’s nature fierce and violent, rebellious and fond of killing, daring and strong. Wherever it shines upon a palace, misfortune follows. If encountered, the household will lack four walls. When meeting auspicious stars, one gains authority. If conjoined with malevolent stars, it brings calamity. Dwelling in this palace, one must break from ancestors, though affairs proceed swiftly. When in its temple or at peak strength, it governs military authority, surely raising banners, standards, and battle-axes. Meeting auspicious stars with nobility in its temple, one attains official emolument and illustrious glory. Conjoined with **Fortune and Virtue**, one breaks from ancestors to establish a household. Conjoined with **Seal and Longevity**, one gains glory and long life. Conjoined with **Wenchang**, one remains pure and solitary. Conjoined with **Treasury**, one is truly wealthy and prosperous. Meeting malevolent stars with **Punishment and Blade**, one harms parents, siblings, wife, and children. It also portends early death in one’s prime. Conjoined with **Punishment**, one is fond of killing; with **Void**, one suffers poverty, cold, and many disasters; with **Weeping**, one becomes a shaman, physician, or one of the nine humble trades, and dies away from home. Conjoined with **Void and Weeping**, one suffers epidemics. When **Three Stars**, **Void Star**, or malevolent stars reside in the **Life Palace** with **Mao**, it foretells a violent and early death. It also portends greed, lewdness, and lust. Meeting **Treasury**, one establishes oneself independently, often staying abroad—if a monk or Daoist, one dies in a foreign land.

In the **Official Emolument Palace**, one fears nothing, sets firm resolve, and makes decisions without doubt. In the **Migration and Fortune Palaces**, one avoids peril and hardship. When transiting or annual stars shine upon it without auspicious stars, one suffers official disasters, water calamities, and extraordinary misfortunes. For women, it is the same, portending childbirth difficulties and weakness in the lungs. If meeting auspicious stars to assist, one may gain or lose fortune through licentiousness, inviting disaster. Conjoined with **Weeping and Blade**, the six relations grow cold and distant.

**Verse:**
In **Zi**, with intent and courage to uphold,
Born at night with auspicious stars, one suffers a fierce wife and many concubines.
A concubine meeting **Celestial Fortune** gains **Purple Tenuity** and wealth.
In **Chou**, with **Fortune and Virtue**, misfortune turns to blessing.
Meeting **Changing Emolument**, one achieves fame and wealth through words and writing—auspicious when in temple or at peak strength.
In **Yin**, one holds authority, granaries overflow, outwardly full but inwardly empty.
Meeting auspicious stars, one is skilled and wealthy, with doubled fortune and nobility.
In **Mao**, one holds heavy office, a scholar of the imperial academy.
Meeting auspicious stars, one gains wealth and nobility; conjoined with malevolent stars to clash and break, one suffers poverty.
In **Chen**, one abandons ancestors, harms others, invites strange misfortunes without punishment, and accomplishes nothing.
Meeting malevolent stars, one suffers punishment and poverty.
In **Si**, one is fickle and inconstant, lonely and suffering, without stability, hesitating between advance and retreat, and the six relations offer no support.
In **Wu**, meeting auspicious stars, one gains noble patronage; conjoined with malevolent stars, one fails more than succeeds, and one’s endeavors are futile.
In **Wei**, one often lacks kinship ties and must leave ancestors to succeed.
Meeting **Celestial Fortune**, **Treasury**, or **Luan**, one gains wealth; if malevolent stars clash, it is inauspicious.
In **Shen**, one is seductive and skilled in poisonous arts.
Meeting malevolent stars, one suffers lifelong poverty, breaks from ancestors, and leaves home; meeting auspicious stars, one gains emolument and longevity.
In **You**, one breaks from ancestors and labors in worry.
Meeting malevolent stars, one dies young and meets no good end; meeting auspicious stars, one may avoid misfortune and find good fortune.
In **Xu**, one breaks from ancestors but turns misfortune to good, gaining much wealth in later years.
Meeting auspicious stars, one ascends as if by cloud ladder; meeting malevolent stars, it is inauspicious.
In **Hai**, one is beset by doubt, fear, and alarm.
Meeting malevolent stars, one’s fortunes fluctuate, gains and losses are uncertain; meeting good stars, it is auspicious.

---

The **Celestial Blade Star**, also called **Hanging Needle of Bloodshed**, is a star of metal, another name for the **Seven Killings** deity. In the **Purple Tenuity Enclosure**, it governs matters of yin virtue but also brings harm and injury. In structural analysis, when it resides in the **Life Palace** of men or women alongside **Blade** and **Treasury**, forming the **Zi Blade Purple Configuration**, it surely destroys the household. When in its temple in **Si (Snake)** or **Shen (Monkey)**, at peak strength in **Wu (Horse)**, or delighting in **Yin (Tiger)** or the **Life Palace**, one’s nature is cruel and wolfish, fond of killing and slaughter, often dying by the blade in battle. Wherever it shines upon a palace, it governs the authority of war and punishment. Meeting malevolent stars, one suffers injury and ruin; meeting auspicious stars, one harms others in silence but can resolve matters favorably. When in its temple and conjoined with auspicious stars, one holds military authority but cannot avoid falling in battle, suffering blood diseases, or being exiled, surely enduring flogging, humiliation, and penal servitude. Meeting auspicious stars with **Purple Tenuity**, misfortune is half reduced. Conjoined with **Treasury** or **Luan**, one has wealth but often dies by hanging, drowning, or beast-inflicted injury. Conjoined with **Seal** or **Longevity**, one may have illness but survive; otherwise, one dies young. Conjoined with **Wenchang**, one holds authority but remains solitary. Conjoined with **Luan**, one is harmed by lust. Conjoined with **Nobility**, one holds authority but meets no good end. Conjoined with **Fortune and Emolument**, one’s fortune is incomplete. Conjoined with **Punishment**, one dies violently. Conjoined with **Mao**, one dies young. Conjoined with **Yao**, one is lewd and dies young. Conjoined with **Void**, one is insubstantial and deceitful; with **Weeping**, one is solitary and harms others. For women, it portends difficult childbirth, strange postpartum illnesses, and weakness in the lungs. In the **Official Emolument Palace**, one’s nature is fierce and violent, not harming others. In the **Migration Palace**, it is inauspicious to encounter; when transiting or in annual stars, it brings sudden disasters and misfortunes—only families that accumulate goodness may avoid them. If conjoined with **Yao** and strange stars, one dies lewdly and young, establishing a separate lineage, and one’s offspring are of a different kind. Neither men nor women should have this star in their **Life Palace**.

**Verse:**
In **Zi**, one indulges in lust, has beautiful women, suffers strange moans and toil, and wanders to the end—yet it is not entirely bad.
In **Chou**, one is drawn to the uncanny, fond of shamans and sorcerers, with flourishing wealth and fields.
Meeting auspicious stars, misfortune is reduced; meeting malevolent stars, one dies by the uncanny.
One practices incantations, writes talismans, and is shamelessly content.
In **Yin**, one dies for lust; women perish from lewdness.
Men are often foolish and dull, mere commoners, with conduct as chaotic as beasts.
In **Mao**, one harms the six relations, suffers from madness and illness, punishes one’s wife, and harms one’s children.
Meeting malevolent stars, one dies young and suffers poverty; even with auspicious stars, it is often mediocre.
In **Chen**, one has ample celestial emolument, but in middle age, one wanders and toils.

**Hai (Pig):** Fortune and emolument illuminate the ancestral pivot, governing the court and palace. In the **Fortune and Virtue** direction, fame spreads; meeting **Treasury, Luan, and Purple**, one attains wealth and nobility.

---

The **Mao-Head Star**, also called the **Celestial Broom**, **Interloper**, or **Sweeping Comet**, is a star of ominous portent. When it guards a palace, it brings two years of disaster and famine. Wherever it shines, misfortune follows.

chunks.original_text: 一生虚碌碌，财禄有无多。 巳财禄耗散，出外身亡，子孙孤苦。 遇吉星可解，逢凶星必克害，其瑞甚微，其祸甚大。 午孤睽午宫，主好色。 妻宫，通外人，能廉礼节，伤残克六亲，曰下临丧，面前可见。 未六亲克害，作事成败。 遇吉星，入来好。 恶曜见之，终不能保守，华而不实者矣。 申凶伴不良，有害则可也。 吉星当头，亦不能济其灾也。 福星临，而祸发以表人。 酉百中无正性，作事多番覆。 性则无定准，损害见刑酷。 戌天殃火星多财禄，虚酉畏恶星，限临恶曜，伤克父母，妻子寿促，主灾疾。 亥亥宫须有害，禄位得阴人。 贵高得宠位，室璧尽忠清。 天刑星，名曰天炮、火星、死符、始始击、计都、虚空、火德、天狗、天权、天害。 此星十名，乃计都星异名，与罗喉星相对，又曰天尾星，士军旅鈇钹之事。 紫微面南，为车骑将帅之宿，遇之则主豪福权贵，忠义贯於曰且，节操凛於冰霜。 主官灾论格局，刑刃星兄弟宫，名破雁格，同虚及居卯上，名坐雷门格，庙寅成旺，酉乐午宫身命二宫，主气象，好折人不平处。 照是宫，主横死，有善星救解，亦主徒流。 若同红贯，庙旺非常，且无狱禁之厄。 戌上，百通； 失地，主法死必然，必主跛足背，腰腿背异疾。 如得地吉，祸轻。 会吉星加紫微得地，声价贵重。 失地，亦主疾厄伤残。 加贵，显达； 加文昌，人庙主孤； 加库、贯，因财有名； 加印寿，有权； 加鸾，有文武之才； 加福禄，无十分全； 加毛，破相好武； 加杖，有权。 如虚，贫薄，须有声名，多虚少实。 加异，过房入赘； 有刃者，徒配流刑； 加毛刃，主天。 女人见之，防克夫损子，外家凌替，产厄虚怯之患。 加姚，淫奔； 加异，重婚再嫁； 加鸾，福禄相夫有封赠； 加寿，寿高。 官禄宫见吉，迁移宫招水火贼盗之危。 运限流年值之，主灾耗。 子　子宫，主哀伤，遇恶曜刑伤，遭毒妨害，短命六亲，主克疾病连乡。 丑　丑宫多克害，贪财并破败。 凶限克双亲，少成多破败。 寅主武寅居号虎威，印禄庙廊居。 居宠臣安乐，雁塔必中书。 忌恶星冲，男子伤妻子，女性刚孤寡，三十岁内少儿，少年有浓血之灾。 卯　腰跎眼目疾，刑害不能安。 僧道须当吉，身孤命又单。 辰　辰宫心地险，封公遇贯虎蛇惊。 刑吊伤亡事，要兔遇吉星。 巳　巳宫损妻子，罗刚克害岂非常。 成败无期准，生来性急刚。 午　外死，主夭折，恶毒咒咀，不良之人，刑妻害子，损六亲。 宜重责己，而轻责人。 未　未宫凶吉两相参，妻儿定主两三番。 六亲有损须破祖，离飨僧道寿宜长。 申　申宫阴毒主刑伤，父母初年定克亡。 命限若无吉星助，灾危成败岂寻常。 酉　酉宫必刑伤，文武妻儿定克亡。 幼年伤父母，带疾夭寿丧。 戌　征伐靖边时色戌宫，禄星属三方吉曜临，或名须自到，无谋定有成。 亥　亥宫孤虚禄，文章克世材。 惊天须动地，天禄自然来。 天姚星，名曰天淫玄娼，主乐将桃花，主桃花撞钗，风流妖诞之宿。 此星在垣局，专主淫秽之事。 论格局，居子位，名花粹宝王格，主淫乱庙卯戌旺辰乐亥身命二宫，主性阴毒，性乱多疑，善颜色福浅之人。 若八庙旺，却富贵多奴婢。 居亥上，名登明之宫，有绝世之才。

A life spent in vain busyness, with wealth and emolument uncertain in abundance.

In **Si**, wealth and emolument dissipate; one dies abroad, leaving descendants orphaned and suffering. Meeting auspicious stars may resolve this, but encountering malevolent stars brings certain harm—the blessings are faint, the misfortunes grave.

In **Wu**, one is solitary and estranged, fond of lust. In the wife’s palace, one consorts with outsiders, yet observes propriety and ritual; still, one harms and severs the six relations, with mourning imminent, visible before one’s eyes.

In **Wei**, the six relations bring harm, and affairs succeed or fail unpredictably. Meeting auspicious stars brings improvement, but if malevolent stars appear, one cannot preserve what one has—all is show without substance.

In **Shen**, evil companions bring harm, though some good may yet arise. Even with auspicious stars overhead, they cannot avert disaster. When the fortune star arrives, misfortune manifests outwardly.

In **You**, one lacks steadfast nature, and actions are often reversed. One’s temperament is unstable, bringing harm and cruel punishments.

In **Xu**, celestial misfortune and fire stars bring abundant wealth and emolument, yet one fears malevolent stars. When the limit meets evil stars, one harms and severs parents, spouse, and children, whose lives are cut short, bringing disaster and illness.

In **Hai**, harm is inevitable in the Hai palace, but emolument and position come through influential women. Those of high rank gain favor and office, their chambers and walls pure in loyalty. The celestial punishment star is called by ten names: Celestial Cannon, Fire Star, Death Talisman, Beginning Strike, Ketu, Void, Fire Virtue, Celestial Dog, Celestial Authority, and Celestial Harm. These are alternate names for Ketu, which opposes Rahu and is also called the Celestial Tail Star, governing military and penal affairs. When the Purple Tenuity faces south, it becomes the constellation of chariot and cavalry generals. Meeting it brings noble fortune, authority, and honor, with loyalty shining like the sun and integrity as unyielding as frost. It governs official disasters in structural fate, and when the execution star resides in the brothers’ palace, it forms the Broken Goose pattern. Together with Void and positioned in Mao, it is called the Sitting Thunder Gate pattern. When in its temple in Yin, flourishing in Chen, joyful in You, or in the Wu palace of the body and life palaces, it governs temperament, often redressing others’ injustices. If it illuminates this palace, it brings violent death; even with benevolent stars to mitigate, one may still face exile. If aligned with the Red Thread, flourishing in its temple, one avoids the calamity of imprisonment. In Xu, all is connected; if it loses its position, legal death is certain, and one will surely suffer from lameness, hunchback, or ailments of the waist, legs, or back. If it gains a favorable position, misfortune is lightened. When meeting auspicious stars and the Purple Tenuity in its proper place, one’s reputation and status are noble and weighty. If it loses its position, one still suffers illness, disaster, and injury. When aligned with nobility, one achieves prominence; with Literary Brilliance, one is in its temple and becomes solitary; with Treasury or Thread, one gains fame through wealth; with Seal and Longevity, one holds power; with Phoenix, one possesses civil and martial talent; with Fortune and Emolument, one is not entirely complete; with Hair, one is disfigured and fond of martial arts; with Staff, one holds authority. If in Void, one is poor and thin, yet must have a reputation, though it is more hollow than substantial. With the Strange star, one is adopted or becomes a son-in-law; with Blade, one faces exile or penal servitude; with Hair and Blade, one dies prematurely. For women, it brings harm to husbands and children, the decline of the maternal family, and the perils of childbirth and weakness. With the Yao star, one is wanton and elopes; with the Strange star, one remarries; with Phoenix, one brings fortune and emolument to her husband and receives honors; with Longevity, one enjoys a long life. If the official emolument palace meets auspicious stars, the migration palace faces dangers of water, fire, bandits, and thieves. When the flow of fortune and the year’s limit encounter it, one suffers disasters and losses.

In **Zi**, the Zi palace brings sorrow; meeting malevolent stars brings punishment and harm, poison and obstruction, short life, severed six relations, and persistent illness.

In **Chou**, the Chou palace brings much harm, greed for wealth, and ruin. Malevolent limits sever both parents, and early success leads to later ruin.

In **Yin**, the martial Yin, dwelling as the Tiger’s Might, resides in the temple of seals and emoluments. As a favored minister, one lives in ease; as a wild goose tower, one surely attains the Secretariat. If struck by malevolent stars, men harm their wives and children, while women become stern and widowed, with few children before thirty and youthful afflictions of thick blood.

In **Mao**, one suffers from waist and eye ailments, punishment, and harm, unable to find peace. Monks and Daoists may fare well, but one’s life is solitary and lonely.

In **Chen**, the Chen palace harbors a treacherous heart; when granted office, one encounters the terror of tigers and snakes. Punishment and misfortune bring injury and death—only meeting auspicious stars like the Rabbit brings relief.

In **Si**, the Si palace harms wives and children; the unyielding Luo and Gang stars bring extraordinary harm. Success and failure have no fixed time, and one is born with a hasty and rigid temperament.

In **Wu**, one dies abroad, meeting an early end, cursed by malevolent and wicked people. One harms wives and children, severs the six relations, and should blame oneself more than others.

In **Wei**, the Wei palace mixes good and ill fortune, with wives and children changing two or three times. The six relations suffer harm, one must break from ancestors, and leaving home to become a monk or Daoist may bring long life.

In **Shen**, the Shen palace brings yin poison and punishment, severing parents in early years. Without the aid of auspicious stars, disasters and dangers are anything but ordinary.

In **You**, the You palace surely brings punishment and harm; in civil or martial pursuits, one’s wives and children are doomed. In youth, one loses parents and suffers illness, meeting an early end.

In **Xu**, when pacifying the frontier in times of war, the Xu palace’s emolument star belongs to the three auspicious directions. If one’s name must be achieved alone, success comes without scheming.

In **Hai**, the Hai palace brings solitude and hollow emolument, yet literary talent severs worldly ties. Stirring heaven and moving earth, celestial emolument naturally arrives.

The Celestial Yao star is called the Celestial Debauchery and Mysterious Harlot, governing music, peach blossoms, and the collision of hairpins, a constellation of wind, flow, seduction, and absurdity. When this star resides in the palace enclosure, it specializes in lewd and filthy affairs. In structural fate, when positioned in Zi, it forms the Flower Essence Treasure King pattern, governing lewdness and chaos. Flourishing in Mao, Xu, and Chen, joyful in Hai, and in the body and life palaces, it governs a yin-poisoned temperament, chaotic and suspicious, with a fondness for beauty but shallow fortune. If in its eight temples and flourishing, one is wealthy and noble, with many servants. In Hai, it is called the Ascending Clarity Palace, possessing talent that surpasses the age.

Men are often foolish and dull, mere commoners, with conduct as chaotic as beasts.
In **Mao**, one harms the six relations, suffers from madness and illness, punishes one’s wife, and harms one’s children.
Meeting malevolent stars, one dies young and suffers poverty; even with auspicious stars, it is often mediocre.
In **Chen**, one has ample celestial emolument, but in middle age, one wanders and toils.

chunks.original_text: 逢吉星，则恋花酒。 会恶曜，破家败业，因色犯刑亡身。 六合，少年夭折。 若临命陷，嫁不用谋，把手成亲，会吉星加寿，有寿； 加库，财； 加紫，刚柔相济，风流； 加贵，多妄多嫔； 加鸾，淫； 会凶星，凶； 加刑刃天，折损父母，并妻儿； 兄弟宫，鸦行失序； 加杖，好色； 近贵，多为隶，隶书写之人； 加异，业祖淫贱独人； 加毛，破祖淫，或於人言不顾行； 加哭，酷毒； 官禄宫，多虚少实，会陷人； 疾厄宫，不宜见，主异疾横伤，因色酒损身。 运限逢之，皆不宜。 入庙则吉，人物美质俊秀，性格风流，狡猾多端，机谋百壮，常招是非，及酒色奢华赌博，必占#1一也，男子值之皆然。 女人加哭毛二星，主自缢、产伤。 判曰 子　吊客子宫主狡猾，阴谋说夭孤。 女作风尘之贱妇，损子及损夫。 丑哭临丑宫威猛更端严，文武清贵有刚权。 须逢恶曜有高贵，九流医术是高强。 此星用文武为宰相，列谐侯者，逢恶冲破也，作九流高士之人。 寅　寅宫招罪青，牢狱更官灾。 凶星相犯照，孤克不聚财。 此星早伤父母，帝疾寿促，身命遭之不吉。 若得吉星相助，福禄昌盛。 卯　威猛更色欲，加吉反为福。 重重财禄旺，又忌恶星觞。 辰　破军威猛之壮象，三方遇恶星， 克父母，主奇食庶生倚亲之命。 巳　巳宫，犯兵刃，毒药伤身命。 若遇天福、天杖臧一半，女主鳏寡。 若遇红鸾，因色伤身，死於他乡。 午　文章有风声，际会荫，豪名帛衣官显，客凶中化吉，星贯索，巫医僧道。 未　主风流、血疾、死亡，身来官禄助，亦夭； 遇红鸾星，可免一半。 申　败常乱家法，先破后家成。 遇恶带重疾，身亡文毋华。 酉　主人一生名标青史，禄贵高迁。 酉宫号矢星，金刃矢害身。 更加恶曜临，刑伤损六亲。 主伤亡父母，破败孤，克家风。 戌　因猛中而失职，恶曜冲照，官灾横恶。 此宫主孤贫非横，恶事临身。 亥#2亥宫在阴邪，家富尽消磨。 恶曜凶星照，官灾产死多。 此宫如遇恶星，男遭官灾，女主产难之厄。 星行限，吉凶论。 紫微星拱限，主荣迁喜庆之事，庶人 营业增产，学主名誉，贵人加官进职，僧道有清高之福，妇人必旺夫家。 亥卯三方会吉星，主面君之荣，庶人发迹。 天虚 天虚名无实，星照限，主利名耗虚危，财帛难骤，仍有虚惊空喜，阴人小口，哭泣孝服，破财之事。 刑哭姚刃冲并，主染蛊肿之病。 虚会刑杀并限者，主招家暗凶事，长吊官制，凡事不吉，主虚痨瘦弱。 亦主贫贱孤苦，一生好事成空，万事到头。 如梦。
chunks.translated_text:
When encountering auspicious stars, one indulges in flowers and wine. When meeting malevolent stars, one ruins family and career, suffers punishment or death due to lust. In the Six Harmonies, one dies young. If residing in the Life Palace in decline, marriage occurs without deliberation, hand-in-hand unions form; meeting auspicious stars adds longevity, with long life; in the Treasury, wealth; in the Purple Palace, hardness and softness balance, with charm; in the Noble Palace, many delusions and concubines; in the Phoenix, lewdness; meeting inauspicious stars brings misfortune; in the Punishment Blade Palace, harm to parents and wife and children; in the Sibling Palace, disorder like crows in flight; with the Staff, fondness for beauty; near nobility, often reduced to servitude, scribes and clerks; with the Strange, ancestral lewdness and lowly solitude; with the Hair, ancestral ruin through lewdness, or heedless of others’ words; with the Weeping, cruelty and poison; in the Official Salary Palace, much emptiness and little substance, ensnaring others; in the Illness and Misfortune Palace, not to be seen, governing strange illnesses and violent harm, bodily damage from lust and wine. In fate and fortune, all are inauspicious. Residing in its temple brings fortune, with beautiful appearance and elegant bearing, charming and cunning, full of schemes, often inciting disputes, indulging in wine, lust, extravagance, and gambling—this is the foremost trait. Men under its influence are all thus. Women with the Weeping and Hair stars suffer hanging or death in childbirth.

**Judgment:**
**Zi:** The Zi Palace’s Mourning Guest governs cunning and intrigue, scheming and early death, leaving one orphaned. Women become lowly prostitutes, harming children and husbands.
**Chou:** The Weeping star in the Chou Palace brings awe-inspiring severity, literary and martial nobility with authority. Meeting malevolent stars brings high rank; in the nine schools, medical skill excels. This star, when used in civil or military roles, makes one a prime minister or feudal lord—if not struck by malevolent stars, one becomes a master of the nine schools.
**Yin:** The Yin Palace invites crime and punishment, imprisonment and official calamity. When inauspicious stars clash, one suffers orphanhood and poverty, unable to amass wealth. This star early harms parents, shortens life with severe illness; in the Life Palace, it is inauspicious. If aided by auspicious stars, fortune and prosperity flourish.
**Mao:** Fierce and lustful, with auspicious stars it reverses to fortune. Wealth and salary flourish, but malevolent stars bring ruin.
**Chen:** The Breaking Army’s fierce and robust image—if the three directions meet malevolent stars, one harms parents, lives as an illegitimate child dependent on relatives.
**Si:** The Si Palace brings blade wounds and poison harm to life. Meeting Heavenly Fortune or Heavenly Staff reduces harm by half; women become widows. Meeting the Red Phoenix, one is harmed by lust and dies in a foreign land.
**Wu:** Literary talent with a reputation, meeting opportunity brings noble rank, official prominence, and fine robes. Inauspicious turns auspicious; the Star of the Hanging Net governs shamans, physicians, monks, and Daoists.
**Wei:** Governs charm, blood illness, and death; if the Official Salary Palace aids, one still dies young. Meeting the Red Phoenix star reduces harm by half.
**Shen:** Defies norms, disrupts family order, first ruins then rebuilds. Meeting malevolence brings severe illness, death, and loss of literary grace.
**You:** One’s name is recorded in history, salary and rank rise high. The You Palace’s Arrow Star brings harm from blades and arrows. With malevolent stars, punishment harms the six relations, causing parental death, ruin, orphanhood, and family decline.
**Xu:** Loses position through ferocity; malevolent stars bring official calamity and violence. This palace governs orphanhood, poverty, and misfortune, with evil befalling the body.
**Hai:** The Hai Palace in yin evil dissipates family wealth. Malevolent stars bring official calamity and many deaths in childbirth. If malevolent stars strike, men suffer official misfortune; women endure difficult births. The star’s transit through fate determines fortune or misfortune.

When the Purple Tenuity star guards fate, it brings honor, promotion, and joyous events; commoners’ enterprises prosper, scholars gain reputation, nobles advance in rank, monks and Daoists enjoy pure blessings, and women strengthen their husbands’ families. The three directions of Hai and Mao meeting auspicious stars bring imperial audience and honor; commoners rise in the world.

**Heavenly Void:**
The Heavenly Void is named for emptiness; when its star guards fate, it brings hollow fame, financial loss, and peril, with sudden wealth elusive. There are false alarms, empty joys, mourning for women and children, funerary clothes, and financial ruin. When Punishment, Weeping, Yao, and Blade stars converge, one suffers from swelling and poisoning. Void meeting Punishment and Killing stars in fate brings hidden family misfortune, long-term official restraint, and inauspiciousness in all matters, leading to consumptive weakness. It also governs poverty, orphanhood, and suffering, with life’s good things turning to nothing, all affairs ending in vain—like a dream.
chunks.overlap_context: s. In structural fate, when positioned in Zi, it forms the Flower Essence Treasure King pattern, governing lewdness and chaos. Flourishing in Mao, Xu, and Chen, joyful in Hai, and in the body and life palaces, it governs a yin-poisoned temperament, chaotic and suspicious, with a fondness for beauty but shallow fortune. If in its eight temples and flourishing, one is wealthy and noble, with many servants. In Hai, it is called the Ascending Clarity Palace, possessing talent that surpasses the age.

chunks.original_text: 天贵 天贵星拱限，喜气非常，无灾有吉， 文人及第，官贵升迁，士庶发财，僧道衣钵充实。 女人遇此，必主荣夫富资帛，有封号。 彖曰 贵星入限喜非常，纵有灾厄亦吉昌。 文者遇之须及第，官贵逢此入朝堂。 天印 天印星拱限，贵人主骤迁显达，士庶则创业兴隆。 贵者主三印之权，生杀之柄。 更在庙旺高强之宫，管领军民，掌握兵权，常人遇贵，僧道清职。 不入局者，居陷弱之宫，亦主近贵发财。 彖曰 运限如逢天印星，迁除骤曜得光荣。 一官连管重重印，职高权重播芳名。 天寿 天寿星拱限，凡事吉利。 更遇吉星， 主荣华显达，寿永灾消。 更须四破无侵，多获吉庆。 红鸾 红鸾星拱限，主财禄吉庆之事，男子必招美妇，女子必配良夫。 如会禄贵，则荣华显达。 如不入庙更加天异，主公私破耗，孝服不宁，失脱横罗之事。 天库 天库星拱限，主发财。 更入庙旺方，骤富之家，开张铺质，常人亦发。 如无刑星，旧发世推当代陶朱，财镇一坊人指当年倚顿。 彖曰 天库之宫中局中，十年之内足财源。 更兼外位相逢好，管取身膺王殿前。 贯索 贯索星拱限，主进财禄。 更在命宫庙旺会地主发天库会之，主得横财。 红鸾拱之，主发财亨利，亦遇高贤荐擢。 三合会吉星，亦主获福。 三合文刑来拱，主招词颂凶事。 若遇吉星拱合，逢恩赦释。 加恶曜，主生离死别，是非破家耗荡，盗贼损害，回禄之事，囊四方之利，网罗六地之资。 彖曰 贯索之星只主财，吉星拱会自然来。 忽然岁限相逢着，资库还均数处开。 又曰 贯禄之星宝上奇，生来囊豪厚金资。 加之岁限相逢处，财禄盈门喜展眉。 又 文昌为天福星拱限，贵人面君，士者展官，庶人进田宅，门庭光彩，栋宇维新。 限到亥卯未宫，亦骤发骤富，僧道清高，常人奋发。 女人临此，夫安子美，于蠹于囊。 遇贵禄星，有封赠。 彖曰

**Heavenly Nobility:**
When the Heavenly Nobility star guards fate, joy is extraordinary, disasters vanish, and fortune prevails. Scholars pass imperial examinations, officials and nobles ascend in rank, commoners prosper in wealth, and monks and Daoists see their robes and alms bowls filled. Women who encounter this star will bring honor to their husbands and amass riches, even receiving titles.
*Verse:*
The Noble star enters fate with boundless joy,
Though trials may come, all turns to good.
Scholars who meet it shall pass the exams,
Officials and nobles ascend the court’s hall.

**Heavenly Seal:**
When the Heavenly Seal star guards fate, nobles swiftly rise to prominence, while commoners establish thriving enterprises. Those of high rank wield the power of three seals, holding life and death in their grasp. If positioned in a flourishing and exalted palace, they command armies and govern the people, wielding military authority. Even ordinary folk who encounter nobility, or monks and Daoists, attain esteemed positions. If not in a dominant configuration but residing in a weak or afflicted palace, they still gain wealth through proximity to the powerful.
*Verse:*
When fate aligns with the Heavenly Seal,
Promotions and honors swiftly reveal.
One office holds seals in layered might,
High rank and fame shine ever bright.

**Heavenly Longevity:**
When the Heavenly Longevity star guards fate, all affairs turn auspicious. Meeting further auspicious stars brings glory, prosperity, and enduring longevity, with disasters dissolved. If the Four Breaks are unopposed, abundant blessings follow.
*Red Phoenix:*
When the Red Phoenix star guards fate, it brings fortune in wealth and rank. Men gain beautiful wives, and women wed worthy husbands. If it meets Wealth and Nobility stars, glory and prosperity abound. If not in its proper palace and further afflicted by celestial anomalies, it brings public and private losses, mourning, unrest, theft, and unexpected calamities.

**Heavenly Treasury:**
When the Heavenly Treasury star guards fate, it brings wealth. If positioned in a flourishing palace, families swiftly grow rich, businesses thrive, and even commoners prosper. Without afflicting stars, those who have long prospered become the era’s Marches of Chen, their fortunes so vast they anchor entire districts, their names synonymous with sudden wealth.
*Verse:*
Within the Heavenly Treasury’s domain,
A decade’s wealth flows without strain.
If outer stars align in grace,
One stands before the royal place.

**Linked Chain:**
When the Linked Chain star guards fate, it brings advancement in wealth and rank. If in the Life Palace, flourishing and meeting the Earthly Lord or Heavenly Treasury, it brings windfall gains. Meeting the Red Phoenix, it brings prosperous fortune and encounters with noble patrons. Triadic alignment with auspicious stars also brings blessings. If triadic alignment involves Literary and Punishment stars, it brings legal disputes and misfortune. If met by auspicious stars, one is released by imperial pardon. If afflicted by malevolent stars, it brings separation, death, lawsuits, family ruin, financial loss, theft, fire, and the scattering of wealth across the four directions, ensnaring resources from all six realms.
*Verse:*
The Linked Chain star governs wealth alone,
With auspicious stars, fortune is shown.
When fate and years align just right,
Treasuries open in full sight.
*Another Verse:*
The Linked Wealth star, a gem so rare,
Born with coffers rich and fair.
When fate and years in union meet,
Wealth fills the gates with joy complete.

**Literary Brilliance:**
When the Literary Brilliance, the Heavenly Fortune star, guards fate, nobles gain imperial audience, officials expand their posts, and commoners acquire fields and estates, their halls radiant and homes renewed. When fate reaches the Hai-Mao-Wei palace, sudden wealth and prosperity arise; monks and Daoists attain purity, while ordinary folk rise swiftly. Women who encounter this star enjoy harmonious husbands and fine children, their silkworms and granaries flourishing. Meeting Nobility and Wealth stars brings titles and honors.
*Verse:*

chunks.original_text: 吉星相照号文昌，士贵逢之姓字扬。 常人遇者增产业，女流僧道值为良。 天福 天福星供限，贵人面君，仕者展官，庶人进田宅，门户清吉，君子官禄升迁，重纳喜庆，财绿丰盈，福禄骈集，乐享高常。 王#3贵常人、僧道，亦主发财增福。 女人膺此，福寿齐临，相夫益子。 彖曰 限逢天福得安康，改换门风家道昌。 钱财进益添人口，定须创造置田注。 天禄 天禄照限主俄然，旧愿新谋事并圆。 灾困徒流须会赦，驳官君子受重宣。 商人暗觅生财利，文武须持两柄权。 到此人情皆庆贺，经营遂意胜如前。 彖曰 天禄宫中事称情，求官得遂禄丰盈。 更兼流岁红鸾照，十年之内贵无伦。 天杖 天仗星拱限，命主风痨、气喘、脚疾、心疼之患，寒热呕逆，及跌蹼之灾，官挠之福，凡事少顺，不宁之悔。 又主孝服、口、舌、拮括。 若加刑刃，主遭拘禁伽锁，无头之祸。 不然，亦主中风寒邪，气喘千正。 若在疾厄宫，主有异疾罹已。 凡所照者，有害无益，生灾癣脓血之灾。 天异 天异星拱限，主产业分散，孝服相仍，及大刑小，并宅下诧异祸事。 若加天姚，主移徙、破耗、公讼、牵继之事。 加恶星，主伤命公治之。 如入庙者，主灾悔。 三方有吉星，不为害。 毛头 毛头照限，主灾病官刑，及移徙不宁，水火盗贱之灾。 如虚哭星钓合，主瘟疫、疮毒、脓血、汤火之伤，回禄之恐。 又忌刑星并冲，不利少吉，多凶破耗，孝服死亡。 若限庙旺之地加善星者，主当贵，及有出师鈇铁兵民之推。 不入庙旺者，所以灾祸不利之事。 三方有吉星拱会，而无害也。 彖曰 天彗毛头不可当，多生灾病主瘟黄。 或然岁岁限皆临，此急去祈求作保。 天刑 天刑星拱限，主官殃不测之灾，及刑狱之福。 主破财，并并陷水厄，刑父母，克弟兄。 加姚异刃星，主耳目昏疼，并血光之咎。 加哭星，主惊恐、灾疾，人离财散之祸。 加天杖，主官刑不吉之事。 会恶曜冲并，主腰驼背曲，手足、耳目异端之患，及五脏不宁，疯疾气喘之灾。 与吉星同宫者，可变恶为祥。 如会凶刑刃哭虚星者，主夭亡也。 天刃 天刃星拱照，主灾祸、破财之事，不利父母、妻儿。 主灾咎刑，并疮疥、血光、异疾、伤损之悔。 女人主产厄之灾，恶毒痈疽之证。 宜守困，切莫进身谋望。 亦主人口灾伤。 孝服重，则伤亡及损寿。 正照并对照，皆主厄难，名利身亡。 亦忌刑星中并，招凶祸等事。 限内并凶星、太岁三合，并恶星入局者，八口之家亡七口，其验如神。 天姚 天姚星照限在水厄之灾。 若加天异，主灾胞破财败坏异端祸事生阴人荼毒勾绊闲非。 如入庙者，变凶为吉。 若加恶星，定主夭亡。 彖曰 运遇天姚岁限同，更兼身命会红鸾。 无心自遇阴人喜，情意相投事事欢。 天哭 天哭星照限，又遇流年恶曜，命不可逃。 如三方拱照，必主外； 孝服见，主死。 三方对合，为浪涛之宿； 照身官，为黄泉星； 三方照限，为浪涛限。 彖曰 波涛浪理十年中，便是王孙莫要逢。 正照傍照皆不吉，刑及相逢寿必终。 此星正照、傍照，皆主危厄。 更逢哭虚相会，主疫非常官事，凶灾。 刑杖刃冲并不得地者，主夭亡。 若哭异相逢，主迁徙流耗，公讼官灾，不测之事。 若哭异姚相会者，主失脱破财，非横之事。
chunks.translated_text:
**Literary Brilliance (Wenchang):**
The auspicious star known as Literary Brilliance shines—
Scholars and officials meet it to see their names ascend.
Commoners who encounter it expand their lands and halls,
While women, monks, and Daoists find it brings good fortune’s call.

**Heavenly Fortune (Tianfu):**
When the Heavenly Fortune star guards fate,
Nobles gain imperial audience, officials rise in state.
Commoners acquire new fields and homes,
Their gates auspicious, their fortunes bright as domes.
The virtuous see promotions, double joys, and wealth untold,
With blessings and prosperity in streams of green and gold.
Kings and nobles, common folk, monks and Daoists too,
All find their fortunes swelling, their blessings ever new.
Women who meet this star enjoy both fortune and long life,
Supporting husbands, nurturing children, free from strife.

*Verse:*
When fate aligns with Heavenly Fortune’s grace,
The household thrives, its fortunes interlace.
Wealth flows in, new lives begin,
Fields and homes expand—blessings enter in.

**Heavenly Emolument (Tianlu):**
When Heavenly Emolument shines upon one’s fate,
Old wishes and new schemes all meet success of late.
Exiles and prisoners soon find reprieve,
While officials receive promotions they long to achieve.
Merchants uncover hidden paths to gain,
And scholars and warriors wield dual domains of reign.
All who encounter this star rejoice and celebrate,
For ventures succeed beyond their former state.

*Verse:*
Within the Heavenly Emolument’s embrace,
Desires for office meet with fortune’s grace.
With Red Phoenix in flow and years aligned,
A decade’s rise leaves peers far behind.

**Heavenly Rod (Tianzhang):**
When the Heavenly Rod star guards fate,
Illnesses arise—consumption, wheezing, foot and heart’s weight,
Chills and fevers, vomiting, falls, and blows,
Official troubles, disquiet, and woes.
Mourning robes, disputes, and strife may follow,
Or confinement in chains, a life hollow.
If the Execution Blade aligns near,
Sudden calamity brings death or fear.
Else, wind-stroke or cold may strike with force,
Leaving breath labored, the body’s course.
If in the Palace of Sickness it resides,
Strange ailments afflict, and suffering abides.
All it touches brings harm, not gain,
With sores, pus, and blood, and endless pain.

**Heavenly Anomaly (Tianyi):**
When the Heavenly Anomaly star guards fate,
Estates disperse, mourning robes accumulate.
Great and small face punishment’s sting,
With strange disasters beneath the home’s eaves clinging.
If joined by Heavenly Maiden, expect moves and loss,
Lawsuits, debts, and disputes—no gain, only cost.
With malevolent stars, life may end,
Or official ruin descend.
If in its temple it resides,
Misfortune lingers, woes abide.
But if three auspicious stars align,
Its harm is checked, its sting benign.

**Hairy Head (Maotou):**
When Hairy Head shines upon one’s fate,
Illness, punishment, and moves await,
With fires, floods, and theft to mar the way,
And restless nights that never stay.
If Void and Wailing stars converge,
Plagues, sores, and burns may surge—
Fire’s wrath or scalding water’s sting,
Or wounds from blades that death may bring.
If Execution stars align in force,
Few blessings come, but ruin’s course.
Mourning robes and deaths may follow near,
With losses vast and woes severe.
Yet if in its temple it stands tall,
With kind stars joining, fortunes call—
Nobility, campaigns, or blades of war,
Or civil ranks to rise once more.
If not in temple, strength, or height,
Disaster strikes with all its might.
But if three auspicious stars appear,
Its harm is checked, its threats disappear.

*Verse:*
The Comet’s Hairy Head brings woe untold,
With plagues and sickness, bodies weak and cold.
If year on year its shadow looms,
Seek prayers and rites to dispel the gloom.

**Heavenly Punishment (Tianxing):**
When Heavenly Punishment guards fate,
Unforeseen official disasters await,
With legal troubles, losses dire,
And water’s perils, drowning’s ire.
Parents may suffer, siblings part,
With broken bonds and heavy heart.
If Maiden or Anomaly align,
Eyes and ears grow dim with pain,
Or bloodshed’s curse may mark the way.
With Wailing stars, fear holds sway—
Illness, terror, partings grim,
With wealth and kin lost on a whim.
If Heavenly Rod joins near,
Official woes bring grief severe.
With malevolent stars in force,
The body bends, its course perverse—
Hunched backs, twisted limbs, and pain,
Or organs failing, breath in vain.
If kind stars share its place,
Evil turns to blessings’ grace.
But with Execution, Wailing, Void,
Life’s thread is cut, fate destroyed.

**Heavenly Blade (Tianren):**
When Heavenly Blade shines bright,
Disaster strikes, wealth takes flight.
Parents and spouse and children too
May face misfortune’s bitter dew.
Illness, punishment, and wounds appear,
With sores, blood, and strange afflictions near.
Women face childbirth’s cruel test,
With abscesses and poisons manifest.
Stay still, avoid ambition’s call,
Lest harm befall and fortunes fall.
Families may see members lost,
With mourning robes and lives exhaust.
If directly or opposingly it glows,
Misfortune follows where it goes.
With Execution stars aligned,
Calamity leaves none behind.
If in the year’s fate it combines,
With malevolent stars in dark designs,
Seven of eight in a household may fall,
Its truth as certain as fate’s call.

**Heavenly Maiden (Tianyao):**
When Heavenly Maiden shines upon one’s fate,
Water’s perils bring ruin and weight.
If joined by Anomaly, expect strife—
Lost wealth, strange woes, and women’s knife,
With entanglements and slander’s sting,
And troubles that no peace may bring.
If in its temple it resides,
Evil turns to blessings’ tides.
But with malevolent stars aligned,
Life’s thread is cut, fate maligned.

*Verse:*
When Heavenly Maiden meets your fate,
With Red Phoenix in years of late,
Unbidden, joy with women flows,
With shared delight in all that grows.

**Heavenly Wailing (Tianku):**
When Heavenly Wailing shines upon one’s fate,
And malevolent stars align in hate,
No escape from fate’s decree remains.
If three directions join its chains,
Exile awaits beyond the door;
With mourning robes, death comes for sure.
If three oppose, the waves will rise;
In life’s palace, the Yellow Springs lies.
If three directions guard one’s fate,
The waves of woe will seal one’s state.

*Verse:*
Waves and tides through ten years’ span,
Even nobles dare not meet this ban.
Direct or slant, its gaze brings dread,
With punishment, life’s thread is shed.
This star’s direct or slanting light
Brings peril, woe, and endless night.
With Wailing and Void in dark array,
Plagues, punishment, and death hold sway.
If Execution and Blade align,
Life’s end is swift, fate’s design.
With Wailing, Anomaly, Maiden near,
Moves, losses, lawsuits bring despair.
If Wailing, Anomaly, Maiden meet,
Lost wealth and sudden woes repeat.
